coredata.dc:description: Regeneration of a sulfur-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst via a temperature ramp in an inert atmosphere with subsequent holding under oxidizing conditions at 500 °C restores significant activity for NO x conversion under standard, fast, and NO2-rich SCR conditions. The N2O selectivity of the regenerated catalyst is higher than for the fresh catalyst under NO2-rich SCR conditions at 280 °C, while the opposite was observed for the standard and fast SCR conditions. Analysis of copper speciation showed that sulfur-free Cu species have different condition-dependent behavior in the fresh and regenerated catalysts. Heating the poisoned catalyst in an oxidizing atmosphere transforms a portion of ammonium sulfates into stable metal sulfates, while heating under inert or reducing conditions leads to more effective desulfation without the formation of stable metal sulfates. Reducing conditions result in desulfation at lower temperatures compared to inert conditions. These results contribute to the further development of regeneration strategies for Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Outlet concentrations of NO, NO2, NH3, and N2O at (a) 220 °C and (b) 280 °C during 11 sequential steps of the NH3-SCR tests for fresh, poisoned, and regenerated Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts: NO x reference steps (1–3), intermediate steps (4,7,9), NH3 saturation step (5), standard SCR (6), fast SCR (8), NO2-rich SCR (10), and the last step (11). The steps are highlighted in Figs. S4–S9. Steps 5–8 for the fresh and poisoned catalysts were reported previously [5]. (c) Inlet gas composition in the steps. N2 was used as balance.

Steady-state (a) NO x conversion and (b) N2O selectivity during standard SCR at 280 °C for the fresh, poisoned, and regenerated Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. The results for the fresh and poisoned catalysts were reported previously [5].

Steady-state (a) NO x conversion and (b) N2O selectivity during fast SCR at 280 °C for the fresh, poisoned, and regenerated Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. The results for the fresh and poisoned catalysts were reported previously [5].
Steady-state (a) NO x conversion and (b) N2O selectivity during NO2-rich SCR at 280 °C for the fresh, poisoned, and regenerated Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts.

(a) The weight loss of the poisoned catalyst during heating in 20% O2/N2 and subsequent heating in N2. (b) The first derivative of the weight loss for the step in N2. A heating rate of 10 °C/min and total gas flow of 100 cm3/min were used.

H2-TPR-MS of the fresh, poisoned, and regenerated Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts: (a) H2 consumption, (b) SO2 concentration, (c) H2S concentration, and (d) NH3 concentration. The MS signals from the empty reactor are also shown. The H2O and O2 MS signals are present in Fig. S10. Inlet 1000 ppm H2 in Ar with a total flow of 20 ml/min was used. The heating rate was 10 °C/min.

Top panel: XANES of (a) fresh, (b) sulfur-poisoned, and (c) regenerated catalysts. Bottom panel: FT EXAFS of (d) fresh, (e) sulfur-poisoned, and (f) regenerated catalysts. The inset of part (a) highlights the white line (WL). The inset of part (b) highlights the second-shell region.

Black dotted lines indicate the substitution of air with He. The temperature axis indicates temperatures applied during the holding stages. The region between 2 and 3 Å is highlighted in Fig. S12. (b) Backscattering amplitude factors attributed to elements of interest [5]. The light gray box shows the range of wavenumbers used in the comparison of components in part (a).

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Regeneration of a sulfur-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst via a temperature ramp in an inert atmosphere with subsequent holding under oxidizing conditions at 500 °C restores significant activity for NO x conversion under standard, fast, and NO2-rich SCR conditions. The N2O selectivity of the regenerated catalyst is higher than for the fresh catalyst under NO2-rich SCR conditions at 280 °C, while the opposite was observed for the standard and fast SCR conditions. Analysis of copper speciation showed that sulfur-free Cu species have different condition-dependent behavior in the fresh and regenerated catalysts. Heating the poisoned catalyst in an oxidizing atmosphere transforms a portion of ammonium sulfates into stable metal sulfates, while heating under inert or reducing conditions leads to more effective desulfation without the formation of stable metal sulfates. Reducing conditions result in desulfation at lower temperatures compared to inert conditions. These results contribute to the further development of regeneration strategies for Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts.

ce:section.ce:para: Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x using ammonia is a widely used deNO x technology in the automotive industry [1]. Copper-exchanged small-pore zeolites such as Cu-SSZ-13 are efficient state-of-the-art NH3-SCR catalysts with excellent SCR performance over a wide temperature range and a high hydrothermal stability [2].

The Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts show a different NH3-SCR performance depending on reaction conditions. The NO2/NO x ratio changes constantly during engine operation and depends on the temperature. As a result, the standard (1), fast (2), and slow (3) SCR reactions can occur:
(1)
4
NH 3
+ 4 NO +
O 2
→ 4
N 2
+ 6
H 2
O
(2)
2
NH 3
+ NO +
NO 2
→ 2
N 2
+ 3
H 2
O
(3)
8
NH 3
+ 6
NO 2
→ 7
N 2
+ 12
H 2
O

Fast SCR conditions (NO2/NO x = 0.5) lead either to decreased activity [3,4] or slightly increased activity [5,6] compared to the standard SCR conditions (NO2/NO x = 0). The NO2-rich (NO2/NO x > 0.5) conditions lead to a decreased low-temperature activity compared to standard SCR conditions [7,8]. The cyclic switching between NO2-rich and NO2-lean conditions improves the overall SCR performance [9].

The N2O selectivity is also dependent on NO2/NO x ratio, with selectivity increasing with increase in NO2/NO x
[10]. The formation of N2O, a strong greenhouse gas, is generally associated with the formation/decomposition of ammonium nitrate [9,11,12]. Formation of ammonium nitrate has been associated with Cu(OH)+ [11] or Brønsted sites [12]. Recent theoretical studies [13] showed that Brønsted acid sites promote the decomposition of ammonium nitrate. The low-temperature N2O formation from H2NNO over Cu-OOH-Cu complexes during the standard SCR reaction has been proposed [13]. Another study excluded ammonium nitrate as a precursor of N2O formation under low-temperature standard SCR [7]. The nature of N2O formation is still debatable.

Sulfur poisoning of Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts severely affects their NH3-SCR performance at temperatures below 350 °C [10]. The sulfur poisoning leads to significant deactivation of the catalyst during the standard SCR reaction, but deactivation of the poisoned catalyst during the fast SCR reaction occurred to a significantly lower extent [5,8,10]. Sulfur-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 showed lower deactivation under NO2-rich conditions compared to standard SCR conditions [8]. N2O selectivity was lower under fast SCR conditions for the sulfur-poisoned catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst [5]. However, the opposite result was also observed previously [10]. The NO2-rich conditions led to a significant increase in N2O selectivity compared to standard and fast SCR conditions for the poisoned catalyst [10]. Nevertheless, a lower N2O selectivity was observed for the poisoned catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst [10]. Further studies on deNO x activity and N2O selectivity of the fresh and sulfur-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts under NO2-rich conditions are beneficial for technology development in order to meet future emission standards.

The sulfur-induced deactivation of Cu-SSZ-13 has been ascribed mainly to the poisoning of active Cu sites [14]. The type and amount of sulfur-containing Cu species formed in Cu-SSZ-13 depends on the poisoning conditions and catalyst composition [15,16]. Carrying out SO2 poisoning in the presence of NH3 leads to the formation of ammonium (bi)sulfates and stable metal (bi)sulfates [15–17]. Ammonium sulfates can also form after exposure of the sulfated catalyst to NH3 [18]. The formation of sulfates is site-dependent [15]. Decreased mobility and suppressed reduction of Cu ions are observed for the sulfur-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst [5]. Our recent computational work exhibits good agreement with experimental studies on sulfur poisoning of Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts [19].

It has been shown that partial regeneration of sulfur-poisoned small-pore Cu zeolite catalysts can be accomplished via exposure to high temperatures (500–550 °C) in oxidizing, inert, or reducing atmosphere [10,15,20–29]. Successful regeneration was observed for heating in an inert atmosphere [26,27]. Less effective regeneration was observed for oxidizing conditions [20,22]. Reducing conditions allowed desulfation at lower temperatures compared to oxidizing conditions [29]. It is thus important to compare the success of desulfation under oxidizing, inert, and reducing conditions within one study.

The effect of NO2/NO x ratio on the NO x conversion and N2O selectivity for NH3-SCR has not been studied for regenerated Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. We present here results for the standard, fast, and NO2-rich SCR over the regenerated Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. Results of three steps (NH3 saturation, standard SCR reaction, and fast SCR reaction) during tests of fresh and sulfur-poisoned Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts were analyzed in our previous study [5]. The results presented here concern other steps in our studies of the fresh and sulfur-poisoned catalysts, including the NO2-rich SCR step. The analysis of both transient effects and steady-state performance is presented here.

Besides partial desulfation, regeneration procedures can lead to the formation of sulfur-free Cu species which are different from the original ones in the fresh catalyst [20,22]. This can also be the reason for changes in NO x conversion and N2O selectivity under various NO2/NO x ratios. To investigate this, the results of NH3-SCR performance tests were linked to the Cu speciation of the regenerated catalysts, which were investigated using a combination of complementary methods: in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), thermogravimetric analysis-mass spectrometry (TGA-MS), hydrogen temperature programmed reduction-mass spectrometry (H2-TPR-MS), X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF), and inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES).

While TGA-MS of the poisoned catalyst was performed in an oxidizing atmosphere previously [5], new results obtained under inert gas conditions are presented here for the poisoned catalyst. While XAS of the fresh and poisoned catalysts was performed using H2/He and CO/He previously [5], new experimental data using air and He are presented here for the fresh, poisoned, and regenerated catalysts. Previously, H2-TPR without MS detection was carried out for the fresh and poisoned catalysts [5]. Results for H2-TPR-MS are presented here for the fresh, poisoned, and regenerated catalysts.

The regenerated catalyst core (d = 21 mm, L = 30 mm) with the Cu-SSZ-13 washcoat deposited on a cordierite substrate (400 cpsi) was tested for SCR activity. The washcoat of the regenerated catalyst core was scraped off after the tests and used in the characterization studies. The washcoats of fresh and poisoned catalyst cores, studied previously [5], were also characterized.

Sulfur poisoning of the catalyst (core) was performed in our previous study in the bench-flow reactor just after the activity test of the fresh catalyst [5]. The fresh catalyst was exposed to 50 ppm SO2, 10% O2, 5% H2O in N2 during 8 h at 280 °C [5]. Then the poisoned catalyst was tested for activity in the same reactor. The bench flow reactor has been described previously [10,30].

Regeneration has been carried out for the sulfur-poisoned catalyst (core) studied previously [5]. Regeneration was performed in the bench-flow reactor after the activity tests of the sulfur-poisoned catalyst. The sulfur-poisoned catalyst was regenerated by heating in N2 flow from 280 to 500 °C, with subsequent holding at 500 °C in 10% O2, 5% H2O for 30 min. Next, cooling from 500 to 220 °C was carried out in N2 flow. The outlet SO2 signal was measured during regeneration (Fig. S1).

The regenerated catalyst (core) has been tested at 220 and 280 °C using the same protocol as used in the previous study for the fresh and sulfur-poisoned catalysts [5]. The protocol consisted of eleven sequential steps (Fig. S2). Only NH3 saturation, standard SCR, and fast SCR steps of the tests of the fresh and sulfur-poisoned catalysts were reported previously [5]. Here we present the full test sequence for the fresh and poisoned catalysts, including NO2-rich SCR.

The ICP-OES analysis was carried out on the regenerated catalyst (washcoat). The weighed sample (weight based on the hydrated sample) was digested with HNO3/HF/H2O (1:1:1) on a hotplate and topped up to 10 cm3 with H2O. A clear solution was observed prior to analysis. Cu∼2.76, Al∼4.7, Si∼26, and Mg∼0.23 wt.% were obtained for the regenerated catalyst.

The XRF analysis for the regenerated catalyst (core) was performed using a PANalytical Epsilon 3XL analyzer to semi-quantitatively determine the molar S/Cu ratio. The sample was mixed with a binder using a ball mill (300 rpm, 10 min) and flat powder briquettes were pressed (150 kN, 3 min). The sample was dried in a furnace for at least 2 h at 105 °C prior to producing the briquette. The molar ratio S/Cu∼0.32 were obtained for the regenerated catalyst.

The thermogravimetric analyzer TGA 8000 and a mass spectrometer Clarus SQ 8T were used for TGA-MS of the poisoned catalyst (washcoat). Prior to the main part of the TGA, the catalyst was heated in situ from room temperature (RT) to 250 °C in 20% O2/N2 and kept at this temperature for 1 h. The O2/N2 was changed to N2 during holding at 250 °C. Next, the temperature was linearly increased from 250 to 900 °C with subsequent holding at 900 °C for 15 min. The heating rate was 10 °C/min. The total flow was 100 cm3/min. The H2O (m/z = 18) and SO2 (m/z = 64) were measured using MS.

The fresh, poisoned, and regenerated catalysts (washcoats) were investigated using a calorimeter setup, described previously [8,31]. 21 mg of each catalyst sample was investigated without in situ pretreatment. The H2 (m/z = 2), NH3 (15), H2O (18), Ar (20), O2 (32), SO2 (64), SO3 (80), H2S (34), and H2SO4 (98) were measured with an MS (Hiden HPR-20 QUI). The total gas flow was 20 ml/min, with 1000 ppm H2 in Ar. The heating rate was 10 °C/min from 25 to 800 °C. The sample was held at 800 °C for 20 min. The obtained signals were smoothed using locally weighted smoothing (LOESS).

In situ Cu K-edge XAS spectra of the fresh, poisoned, and regenerated catalysts (washcoats) were measured in transmission mode at the XAFCA beamline of the Singapore Synchrotron Light Source (SSLS) using an in situ sample cell [32]. Prior to XAS studies samples were heated in flowing air at 300 °C in a furnace for 1 h, and kept under ambient conditions until the measurements. The 100 mg powder samples were pressed into 10 mm diameter pellets. One experimental run per sample was performed. The Cu K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) regions were measured during two stages of each run (Fig. S3). The total gas flow was fixed at 100 cm3/min. The heating and cooling rate was 5 °C/min. The spectral acquisition took 7 min per scan.

The relative rate constant of regenerated catalyst for standard SCR reaction was computed using the following equation:
(4)
Relative
rate
constant
=
ln ( 1 − X )
ln ( 1 −
X f
)
,
where X is NO conversion of the regenerated catalyst, and X
f is NO conversion of the fresh catalyst. The standard SCR reaction was assumed to be a first order with respect to NO, and zero order with respect to NH3.

The Larch software was used for processing the XAS data [33]. The first inflection point (maximum of the 1st derivative) at 8979 eV in the Cu foil spectrum was used for energy calibration. R-space Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra were obtained via the Fourier transform (FT) of k2-weighted EXAFS functions over the 2.5–10.5 Å−1 k-range using a Kaiser-Bessel window. The Cauchy wavelet was used as the mathematical kernel for the wavelet transform (WT) of Cu K-edge EXAFS data [34].

Every five consecutive scans in the Cu K-edge XAS data were merged, resulting in 10 spectra for each run instead of the original 50. The combined XAS dataset containing the 30 XAS spectra for the fresh, poisoned, and regenerated catalyst samples were then created. Next, multivariate curve resolution alternating least square (MCR-ALS) analysis [35] based on Matlab software was applied to the combined dataset for determination of chemically meaningful pure spectra. The combined XAS dataset was represented as a matrix that was bilinearly decomposed by means of singular value decomposition. The optimization of components was performed using the ALS algorithm. The non-negativity constraint was applied.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Transient effects in NH3-SCR performance tests

ce:section.ce:para: NO x reference steps 1, 2, and 3 were performed using sequential NO2/NO x ratios of 0, 0.5, and 0.75, respectively. Step 1 at 220 °C shows a transient drop in outlet NO signal for fresh, poisoned, and regenerated catalysts (Fig. 1 (a)). Simultaneously, outlet NO2 is observed, indicating an oxidation of NO to NO2. This effect is less pronounced for the regenerated catalyst compared to the fresh and poisoned catalysts.

Once conditions of step 2 are applied at 220 °C, the N2O spikes appear for the fresh catalyst and empty reactor (Figs. 1(a) and S4). The fresh catalyst also shows a small N2O spike once conditions of step 3 are applied. The formation of N2O is generally associated with the decomposition of ammonium nitrate [9]. However, another source of N2O is present here because the fresh catalyst was degreened at 500 °C in the same reactor before step 1 at 220 °C [5].

The beginning of steps 2 and 3 at 220 °C shows that the outlet NO2 signal reaches the inlet signal more slowly for the fresh catalyst compared to the poisoned catalyst (Figs. 1(a) and S4). This effect is not observed for the poisoned catalyst. The behavior of the catalyst is not restored completely after regeneration.

Steps 1 and 2 at 280 °C show a decreased outlet NO signal for the poisoned catalyst (Fig. 1(b)). This can be associated with the reaction of NO with ammonium sulfates [18]. In contrast to 220 °C, a temperature of 280 °C appears to be high enough for this reaction. This effect is also observed for the NO2 at step 2 at 280 °C. The regenerated catalyst shows no such effects, indicating the absence of ammonium sulfates.

The NH3 saturation step 5 was reported for the fresh and poisoned catalysts in our previous study [5]. Step 5 starts after the intermediate step 4. The fresh and poisoned catalysts show no significant differences in the NH3 storage capacity [5].

The regenerated catalyst shows an NH3 saturation profile that is similar to the fresh and poisoned catalysts at both 220 and 280 °C (Fig. 1(a) and (b)). Regeneration does not lead to changes in the NH3 storage capacity of the catalyst. This correlates with previous results for a Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst regenerated at 700 °C [10].

The standard SCR step 6 was reported for the fresh and poisoned catalysts in our previous study [5]. Step 6 starts after the NH3 saturation step. The behavior of NO and NH3 signals at 220 °C is restored after regeneration to nearly that of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 1(a)). However, the outlet NH3 signal remains slightly higher for the regenerated catalyst compared to that observed for the fresh catalyst. This correlates with higher outlet signals of NO and N2O for the regenerated catalyst.

Once conditions of step 6 are applied at 220 °C, the regenerated catalyst shows a N2O spike that is similar to that seen for the fresh catalyst (Fig. 1(a)). The poisoned catalyst shows only a minor spike. Thus, the amplitude of the N2O spike is restored after regeneration. Following these spikes, the N2O concentrations rapidly reach steady-state for all catalysts. Similar N2O spikes were observed and attributed to the transition of oxidized to a partially reduced catalyst state [7].

The behavior of outlet gas concentrations during the test of the regenerated catalyst at 280 °C is similar to that seen for this catalyst at 220 °C (Fig. 1(b)). However, lower outlet NO and NH3 signals are observed at 280 °C compared to 220 °C. The N2O spikes are also observed for the regenerated catalyst once conditions of step 6 are applied at 280 °C.

The fast SCR step 8 was reported for the fresh and poisoned catalysts in our previous study [5]. Step 8 starts after the intermediate step 7. In contrast to the poisoned catalyst, the regenerated catalyst shows steady-state outlet gas signals at 220 °C (Fig. 1(a)). Thus, the regenerated catalyst is not changed during the test as is observed for the poisoned catalyst. The behavior of the regenerated catalyst is restored to that seen for the fresh catalyst. This is also observed for step 8 at 280 °C (Fig. 1(b)). However, decreased N2O production is observed for the regenerated catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst at both 220 and 280 °C.

The NO2-rich SCR (step 10) starts after the intermediate step 9. Step 10 shows that steady-state outlet signals of all gases are not reached at 220 °C for both the fresh and regenerated catalysts (Fig. 1(a)). A monotonic increase in outlet signals of NO, NO2, and NH3 is observed during the entire step 10. At the same time, the outlet N2O signal monotonically decreased for the fresh and regenerated catalysts. Steady-state outlet NO2 and NH3 signals at 220 °C are not reached for the poisoned catalyst, although NO conversion and N2O production does reach steady-state (Fig. 1(a)). A monotonic increase in outlet NO2 and NH3 signals is observed during the course of step 9 at 220 °C for the poisoned catalyst. The outlet NO, NO2, and N2O signals are steady for all catalysts during the tests at 280 °C (Fig. 1(b)).

Once conditions of step 11 are applied at 220 °C, the outlet NO signal instantly increases for all catalysts (Fig. 1(a)). This increase is higher for the poisoned catalyst compared to the fresh and regenerated catalysts. Next, the outlet NO signal starts to decrease gradually for all catalysts. The fresh and regenerated catalyst shows a similar behavior of outlet NO signals at 220 °C.

The NO2 production at 220 °C is observed simultaneously with NO consumption (Fig. 1(a)). This NO2 production can result from the reaction of NO with ammonium nitrate. Thus, NO is consumed during step 11 at 220 °C due to both reaction with ammonia stored at the catalyst and reaction with ammonium nitrate that was formed in excess during the previous step 10. As the reactive ammonia and ammonium nitrate are depleted from the surface of the catalyst, the outlet NO concentration gradually increases again, reaching nearly the inlet NO level.

Step 11 at 280 °C shows that outlet NO concentration increases rapidly for all catalysts (Fig. 1(b)). However, the outlet NO signal is lower than the inlet signal for all catalysts at the end of the step. It is likely that some ammonia has remained on the fresh catalyst. This ammonia can react with SO2 during the following sulfur poisoning step at 280 °C, resulting in the formation of ammonium sulfates.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Steady-state NO x conversion and N2O selectivity

ce:section.ce:para: The standard SCR was reported for the fresh and poisoned catalysts in our previous study [5]. The NO conversion is severely decreased for the poisoned catalyst, resulting in a relative rate constant of 0.08 and 0.14 at 220 and 280 °C, respectively [5]. The N2O selectivity at both 220 and 280 °C decreases for the poisoned catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst [5]. Regeneration restores a major part of the catalytic activity for the standard SCR reaction at 280 °C (Fig. 2 (a)). The relative rate constant is increased after regeneration to around 0.75 and 0.85 at 220 and 280 °C, respectively. The N2O selectivity at 280 °C is increased after regeneration, although this value is lower than for the fresh catalyst (Fig. 2(b)).

The fast SCR was reported for the fresh and poisoned catalysts in our previous study [5]. The poisoned catalyst shows a significantly increased NO x conversion for the fast SCR conditions compared to the standard SCR conditions at 280 °C [5]. The NO x conversion over the poisoned catalyst during the fast SCR reaction at 280 °C is only slightly lower than that observed for the fresh catalyst [5]. At the same time, the N2O selectivity during the fast SCR at 280 °C is significantly lower for the poisoned catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst [5]. Regeneration restores NO x conversion at 280 °C to the level of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 3 (a)). At the same time, a lower N2O selectivity at 280 °C is observed for the regenerated catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst (Fig. 3(b)).

The steady-state NO x conversion over fresh, poisoned, and regenerated catalysts at 280 °C is lower for the NO2-rich SCR conditions compared to the fast SCR conditions (Fig. 4 (a)). At the same time, the N2O selectivity is significantly increased for all catalysts under NO2-rich SCR conditions at 280 °C compared to both the standard and the fast SCR conditions (Fig. 4(b)). In contrast to standard and fast SCR, the regenerated catalyst shows a higher N2O selectivity compared to the fresh catalyst for NO2-rich SCR at 280 °C.

The TGA of the poisoned catalyst consisted of the dehydration step in O2/N2 and the main step in N2 (Fig. 5 (a)). The MS was used to identify weight loss in the TGA experiment. Weight loss during the first 20 min of the dehydration step is assigned to the desorption of H2O (m/z = 18). The main TGA step starts from the 80th minute. The first derivative of the weight loss was used for the analysis of this step (Fig. 5(b)). The first small shoulder at around 345 °C is assigned to H2O (m/z = 18). The significant peak at 450 °C and shoulder at around 580 °C are assigned to SO2 (m/z = 64). We attribute this temperature region to the decomposition of ammonium sulfates [5,36]. Another peak, which starts to develop at around 780 °C, is observed at 890 °C. No significant SO2 MS signal is observed at these temperatures. We attribute this peak to the beginning of zeolite degradation. Note that the TGA-MS profile analyzed here is different from that observed during heating in an oxidizing atmosphere [5]. We discuss the crucial differences between the decomposition of ammonium sulfates in inert and oxidizing atmospheres below.

The H2 consumption peak from 200 to 450 °C with a maximum at around 348 °C is observed for the fresh catalyst (Fig. 6 (a)). Note that the position of H2-TPR peaks are affected by Si/Al, Cu/Al, and experimental conditions [37]. This complicates the direct identification of the peak at 348 °C using a comparison with previous studies [8,12,36–38]. We suggest the same interpretation of the Cu species for the fresh catalyst as proposed in our previous study [5]. However, the fresh catalyst was studied using a higher H2 concentration in our previous study [5]. The decreased H2 concentration applied here shifts the reduction peaks to higher temperatures due to a slower reaction. The peak at 348 °C can be attributed to a superposition of contributions from the reduction of CuII to CuI. The peak at 551 °C can be attributed to the reduction of some CuI to Cu0. The peaks at 588 and 770 °C are observed in the NH3 profile of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 6(d)). These peaks are attributed to NH3 desorption from strong Brønsted acid sites and some NH3 production via a reduction of nitrates by H2.

The poisoned catalyst shows H2 consumption peaks at 409, 572, and 760 °C (Fig. 6(a)). A similar profile has also been observed previously [8]. The poisoned catalyst shows a significantly higher total H2 consumption compared to the fresh catalyst. The first peak in the profile of the poisoned catalyst is shifted to higher temperatures compared to the first peak in the profile of the fresh catalyst. These observations agree with previous studies [5,37]. The SO2 MS signal is detected at 401 °C (Fig. 6(b)). Thus, the H2 consumption peak at 409 °C can be attributed to the reduction of sulfates. H2 consumption peaks at 572 and 760 °C are attributed to H2S production since H2S MS signal is also observed at temperatures higher than 500 °C (Fig. 6(c)). The H2S production has also been detected in previous studies [8,31]. In general, the NH3 profiles of the fresh and poisoned catalyst are similar (Fig. 6(d)). This indicates similar pathways for NH3 release. However, a higher NH3 signal shifted to lower temperatures is observed for the poisoned catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst. This difference is associated with ammonium sulfates noted above. The SO3 and H2SO4 MS signals were not detected.

The H2 consumption peak at 334 °C for the regenerated catalyst is located at lower temperatures and is narrower compared to the first peak for the fresh catalyst (Fig. 6(a)). This can be associated with an increased fraction of Cu x O y species [36,38]. The H2 consumption peak between 550 and 750 °C for the regenerated catalyst, with a maximum around 633 °C can be associated with the formation of H2S since the H2S production peak is located at similar temperatures (Fig. 6(c)). Some H2 consumption on the reduction of CuI to Cu0 can also be seen in this temperature region. The SO2 signal at 478 °C for the regenerated catalyst is attributed to the decomposition of stable metal sulfates (Fig. 6(b)). The presence of a low-temperature peak at 372 °C in the NH3 profile of the regenerated catalyst suggests a new pathway that is not observed for the fresh and poisoned catalysts (Fig. 6(d)). We attribute this to the desorption of NH3 from Cu x O y species of the regenerated catalyst.

Differences in the behavior of the XANES and FT EXAFS regions are observed for the studied catalysts during the heating/cooling in air and subsequent heating in He (Fig. 7 (a)–(f)). Changes in the XANES white line region (around 8996 eV) and pre-edge region (between 8980 and 8990 eV) during the in situ experiment are more pronounced for the fresh catalyst than for the poisoned catalyst. The facile response of the fresh catalyst to changes in environmental conditions is also evident in the FT EXAFS region. The FT EXAFS region of the fresh catalyst shows facile changes in magnitude of the first peak at around 1.4 Å during the experiment. The magnitude of the first FT EXAFS peak is higher for the fresh catalyst compared to the poisoned catalyst when the same experimental conditions are applied. The FT EXAFS of the poisoned catalyst shows a decreased magnitude in the region between 2 and 3 Å compared to the fresh catalyst. It is clearly seen that the behavior of both the XANES and FT EXAFS regions is not restored to the level of the fresh catalyst after regeneration. Significant differences in condition-dependent behavior between the fresh and regenerated catalysts are seen in the XANES region. Moreover, while the poisoned catalyst shows a decreased magnitude of the second FT EXAFS peak compared to the fresh catalyst, the regenerated catalyst shows an increased magnitude. This indicates that regeneration leads to the formation of Cu species with a local coordination environment which differs compared to that is seen in the fresh catalyst.

ce:section.ce:section-title: MCR-ALS: heating and cooling in air
ce:section.ce:para: To reveal the differences in the Cu speciation of the catalysts, a more detailed analysis of the XAS data was carried out using the MCR-ALS approach. Five pure XAS spectra (PC1–PC5) were derived using MCR-ALS analysis of the combined dataset containing the spectra of the fresh, poisoned, and regenerated catalysts.

The component PC1 is attributed to the hydrated Cu ions based on the shape of the XANES region (Fig. 8 (a)). A significant fraction of PC1 is observed at RT for all catalysts (Fig. 9 (a)–(c)). The first FT EXAFS peak of PC1 (Fig. 8 (b)) and lobe A in the WT EXAFS of PC1 (Fig. 10 (a)) are attributed to scattering events associated with first-shell atoms around absorbing Cu ions. These atoms belong to ligands located in equatorial positions around hydrated Cu ions. The WT EXAFS of PC1 also shows features B and C at radial distances higher than 2 Å that can be attributed to ligands in axial positions around absorbing Cu ions and more distant scatterers, respectively [39].

Heating of the fresh catalyst in air leads to a decrease in the fraction of PC1 with simultaneous formation of PC5 (Fig. 9(a)). This PC5 can be attributed to the intermediate dehydrated state of Cu ions [40]. The WT EXAFS of PC5 shows a less intense lobe M compared to lobe A of PC1 (Fig. 10 (a)). This indicates a decrease in the coordination number in the first shell of the absorbing Cu ions. Some differences in the region of radial distance greater than 2 Å are observed between WT EXAFS of PC1 and PC5 due to the partial removal of water ligands. While the fraction of PC5 is abundant for the fresh catalyst, the regenerated catalyst shows a suppressed formation of PC5 (Fig. 9(a) and (c)). The profile of the poisoned catalyst shows the absence of PC5 (Fig. 9(b)).

The removal of water ligands allows the interaction of Cu ions with the framework atoms [41]. This process is associated with the formation of PC2 in the profile of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 9(a)). The decreased intensity of the XANES white line and the more developed shoulder at around 8986 eV are observed for PC2 compared to PC5 (Fig. 8(a)). The feature at around 8986 eV is attributed to the electronic transitions associated with CuII species. The presence of intensity in the region at 8983 eV indicates a small contribution from CuI. The extraction of a pure CuI component is not feasible within the available data quality. The appearance of a minor fraction of CuI during heating of Cu-SSZ-13 under oxidizing conditions was also observed previously [42].

WT EXAFS lobe D of PC2 shows a decreased magnitude compared to lobe M of PC5 due to decreased first-shell coordination number (Fig. 10(a)). Lobe F is less intense compared to lobe P of PC5, indicating differences associated with distant scatterers. A well-defined lobe E between 2 and 3 Å is present for PC2. This region of radial distances is attributed to scattering events associated with the framework Al/Si atoms and second-shell Cu atoms [43]. The WT EXAFS correlates with the backscattering amplitude factor, allowing direct identification of second-shell atoms around the absorber (Fig. 10(b)). Thus, the shape of lobe E indicates the nature of the second-shell atoms involved in the scattering events. The lobe E is slightly broadened in the region with k < 5 Å−1. Thus, lobe E can indicate increased contributions from Al/Si/O and decreased contributions from second-shell Cu atoms. To summarize, PC2 is attributed mainly to the isolated dehydrated CuII with a minor fraction of CuI.

The formation of PC2 is observed in different temperature ranges for the fresh and regenerated catalysts (Fig. 9(a) and (c)). The maximum PC2 fraction is observed between 300 and 400 °C for the fresh catalyst, while the maximum PC2 fraction for the regenerated catalyst is observed at 200–300 °C. The formation of PC2 is significantly suppressed in the poisoned catalyst (Fig. 9(b)). The presence of PC2 in the profile of the poisoned catalyst could indicate that some Cu species remain unaffected by sulfur. Moreover, the behavior of this small fraction of PC2 is more similar to the behavior of this component for the fresh catalyst than for the regenerated catalyst. To summarize, the regeneration leads to the formation of sulfur-free Cu species with condition-dependent behavior that is different from that in the fresh catalyst.

In contrast to the fresh catalyst, the profile of the poisoned catalyst shows the presence of PC3 (Fig. 9(b)). The inset of Fig. 8(a) highlights the significant difference in the XANES white line of PC3 compared to the white lines of both PC2 and PC4. This difference indicates the changes in charge-transfer processes between Cu ions and their surrounding ligands. The position and shape of lobe H in the WT EXAFS of PC3 indicate the nature of second-shell atoms involved in scattering events. The shift in position of lobe H to lower radial distances compared to E and K, indicates changes in the nature of the second-shell atoms (Fig. 10(a)). The backscattering amplitude factor is dependent on the atomic number of the elements (Fig. 10 (b)). Therefore, the low WT magnitude of lobe H in the region of wavenumbers around 7 Å−1 and higher indicates the absence of scattering events associated with second-shell Cu ions. This suggests the absence of multinuclear Cu species in PC3. Therefore, an abundant fraction of PC3 in the profile of the poisoned catalyst indicates the absence of Cu x O y in the poisoned catalyst [5]. Sulfur atoms can significantly contribute to the second coordination shell around the Cu ions of PC6, affecting the shape and the position of the second lobe [5]. PC3 can be associated with highly dispersed Cu sulfate species in the poisoned catalyst. The profile of the regenerated catalyst shows the presence of PC3, indicating incomplete deSO x (Fig. 9(c)).

While the profiles of the fresh and regenerated catalysts show a considerable presence of PC4, the formation of PC4 is suppressed for the poisoned catalyst (Fig. 9(a)–(c)). An increase in the fraction of PC4 consistently accompanies a decrease in the fraction of PC2 for all catalysts. While the fraction of PC4 starts to increase in the profile of the fresh catalyst during cooling down, a significant fraction of PC4 is observed for the regenerated catalyst during heating at 300–400 °C as well. The highest fraction of this component is observed after cooling the catalysts to 200 °C. The lobe K in the WT EXAFS of PC4 is significantly more intense than lobes E and H (Fig. 10(a)). The presence of a sub-lobe extended into the region of wavenumbers higher than 7 Å−1 can indicate the presence of scattering contributions associated with second-shell Cu ions, originating from the Cu x O y . Thus, lobe K can be associated with second-shell Cu atoms of Cu x O y . Note that the interaction of transient CuI with O2 was suggested as a possible pathway to the formation of various multinuclear Cu-oxo species [42]. Some minor fraction of CuI was found in PC2. Thus, the transformation of PC2 to PC4 agrees with the proposed association of Cu x O y with PC4.

The concentration profile of the fresh catalyst shows the transformation of PC4 to PC2 during heating of the fresh sample in He (Fig. 9(a)). This indicates the facile response of the Cu species of the fresh catalyst to changes in temperature. Only a small fraction of PC2 is observed for the poisoned catalyst during heating in He, indicating that the state of Cu ions is frozen in the poisoned catalyst (Fig. 9(b)). This can also be associated with decreased mobility of the Cu ions in the poisoned catalyst [5]. An increased fraction of PC4 is observed in the regenerated catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst at low temperatures (Fig. 9(a) and (c)). Moreover, the regenerated sample also shows suppressed transformation of PC4 to PC2 during heating in He. This again shows different condition-dependent behavior of Cu species in the fresh and regenerated catalysts.

The deSO x efficiency is different under inert and dry oxidizing conditions. Based on our previous study [5], the TGA-MS of the poisoned catalyst under dry oxidizing conditions shows a peak at around 730 °C attributed to the decomposition of stable metal sulfates. In contrast, no weight loss is observed at these temperatures for the poisoned catalyst during heating in N2. This suggests that ammonium sulfates decompose in N2 without any transformation to stable metal sulfates. Thus, heating under inert conditions leads to a more facile decomposition of ammonium sulfate species compared to heating under dry oxidizing conditions. Wijayanti et al. [16] also observed the transformation of ammonium sulfates to Cu sulfates during a temperature ramp in humid oxidizing conditions, while this was not present during a temperature ramp in inert condition.

The TGA-MS results explain the absence of significant desorption of SO2 during the second step of regeneration under humid oxidizing conditions at 500 °C. The first step in the regeneration procedure, heating to 500 °C in N2, led to the significant decomposition of sulfates present in the form of ammonium sulfates. Since temperatures slightly higher than 500 °C are required to completely decompose ammonium sulfates under inert conditions, a portion of ammonium sulfate species does not decompose during the first step of the regeneration in N2. The subsequent exposure to humid oxidizing conditions during the second stage of the regeneration then leads to the transformation of these remaining ammonium sulfates to stable metal sulfates.

The desorption of SO2 associated with the decomposition of ammonium sulfates is observed at lower temperatures in the H2-TPR-MS experiment compared to the TGA-MS. Thus, sulfur removal is possible at lower temperatures under H2-containing reducing conditions compared to inert conditions. Wei et al. [44] also observed the decomposition of sulfate species at lower temperatures in the reducing gas (NH3/NO) than in the inert gas. Kumar et al. [29] proposed that regeneration using NH3/NO can be achieved at temperatures below 400 °C.

While regeneration under inert conditions is not really feasible, the implementation of the regeneration steps using reducing conditions is possible. While regeneration using NO/NH3 can be easily implemented in urea-SCR systems by NH3 overdosing at elevated temperatures [29], the regeneration with H2 can be implemented in the combined LNT-SCR systems using the dosing of H2-containing reformate substitute gas [45]. The concentration of H2 should be significantly decreased and high temperatures should be avoided because of the possible deactivation due to the formation metallic Cu nanoparticles [5,46]. Reducing conditions would be beneficial since this allows complete desulfation of the poisoned catalyst at temperatures below 500 °C. In contrast, oxidizing conditions can lead to the accumulation of stable metal sulfates in the catalyst. Such stable metal sulfates can be removed under oxidizing conditions only at temperatures higher than 700 °C. These high temperatures can lead to hydrothermal aging of a Cu zeolite catalyst, resulting in its irreversible deactivation due to the dealumination. Furthermore, such high temperatures can lead to the deterioration of various components in an aftertreatment system. Therefore, the development of regeneration strategies using temperatures not higher than 500 °C is beneficial for the increased durability of aftertreatment systems. This also helps to avoid the fuel penalty of high temperature regeneration, since relatively low temperatures are enough for complete desulfation under these reducing conditions.

Because of the differences in conditions used in the NH3-SCR and XAS studies, only general indirect correlations between Cu speciation and low-temperature catalytic activity can be provided. Based on the XAS results, the fresh catalyst shows a facile response to changes in temperature during heating/cooling in air and He. The transformation of isolated Cu species to Cu x O y species and in the opposite direction is observed for the fresh catalyst during in situ XAS studies. Note that the formation of various Cu x O y species in Cu-SSZ-13 was also proposed previously [47,48]. The facile transformation of Cu species with changes in environmental conditions can indirectly indicate the high reactivity and mobility of Cu ions in the fresh catalyst. This correlates with the high catalytic activity of the fresh catalyst during the standard SCR reaction [5]. Thus, XAS results for the fresh catalyst reported here are in line with the structure–activity relationships proposed previously [5].

The XAS results for the sulfur-poisoned catalyst show the presence of the component (PC3) associated with the presence of sulfates. The abundance of this XAS component in the MCR-ALS profile of the poisoned catalyst correlates with the significant deactivation of the poisoned catalyst observed during the standard SCR reaction [5]. The changes in the local coordination environment of the poisoned Cu ions and the transformation of one type of Cu species to another are suppressed for the poisoned catalyst. The behavior of Cu ions in the poisoned catalyst observed here agrees with that found in our previous study where suppressed redox and mobility of Cu ions in the poisoned catalyst were detected [5].

The regenerated catalyst shows a mixture of Cu species with similar XAS fingerprints as observed for the species of both the fresh and the poisoned catalysts. The presence of the poisoned component (PC3) in the MCR-ALS concentration profile of the regenerated catalyst agrees with XRF results. This confirms the incomplete desulfation of the catalyst. Based on H2-TPR-MS, the remaining sulfur in the catalyst can be associated with stable metal sulfates. The presence of these stable sulfur species partially contributes to a decreased catalytic activity of the regenerated catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst. Based on XAS, the sulfur-free Cu species formed in the regenerated catalyst show condition-dependent behavior which is different from that observed for the fresh catalyst during heating/cooling in air and He. The total fraction of PC4 is more abundant for the regenerated catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst, while the total fraction of PC2 is decreased. Thus, isolated Cu species are not restored after regeneration to the same state and amount as was present in the fresh catalyst. An increased fraction of multinuclear Cu species is observed after regeneration. The regeneration-induced modifications of Cu species affect the catalytic activity. It has been found recently that Cu x O y species contribute greatly to the low-temperature activity of Cu-SSZ-39 [38]. We also recognize the Cu x O y species of the regenerated catalyst as active sites for NH3-SCR. A decreased amount of Cu(OH)+ in the regenerated catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst results in a decreased N2O selectivity under standard and fast SCR conditions. However, the Cu x O y of the regenerated catalyst leads to increased N2O selectivity under NO2-rich SCR conditions.

The NH3-SCR performance of fresh, sulfur-poisoned, and regenerated Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts was evaluated under standard, fast, and NO2-rich conditions. The characterization of catalysts was performed using a range of in situ methods. The results provide insights into the effect of the regeneration under a combination of inert and oxidizing conditions on the NO x conversion and N2O selectivity during various SCR reaction pathways depending on the NO2/NO x ratio. Significant differences in the condition-dependent Cu speciation in the fresh and regenerated catalysts were found. Based on this study, the following was concluded:
•
The regeneration of the sulfur-poisoned catalyst via a temperature ramp in an inert atmosphere with subsequent holding under oxidizing conditions at 500 °C significantly restores NO x conversion under standard, fast, and NO2-rich SCR conditions.
•
The N2O selectivity of the regenerated catalyst was seen to be higher than for the fresh catalyst under NO2-rich SCR conditions at 280 °C while the opposite was observed for the standard and fast SCR conditions.
•
The regeneration of the catalyst led to the presence of sulfur-free monomeric and multinuclear Cu species with condition-dependent behavior differing from that observed for the fresh catalyst.
•
Heating of the sulfur-poisoned catalyst in inert conditions showed effective removal of sulfur species in the form of ammonium sulfates at temperatures around 500 °C.
•
Heating of the sulfur-poisoned catalyst in oxidizing conditions led to the partial transformation of ammonium sulfates to more stable metal sulfates.
•
Heating of the sulfur-poisoned catalyst under H2-containing reducing conditions resulted in effective desulfation at temperatures lower than is observed under inert conditions.

These results reveal that even though regeneration via a temperature ramp in an inert atmosphere with subsequent holding under oxidizing conditions at 500 °C does not reverse the copper speciation to the original state, relatively high deNO x activity of the regenerated catalyst is obtained. A heating under reducing and inert conditions leads to more effective desulfation of the catalyst than under oxidizing conditions, due to the lack of transformation of ammonium sulfates to stable metal sulfates. The effective removal of ammonium sulfates from the catalyst without transformation into more stable metal sulfates is important for the development of regeneration strategies.
